questions.text: A 40 year old woman with three children who has been using OCPs for 5 years is a current smoker, has a BMI of 27, menarche at 13, and has a family history of endometriosis, is concerned about her risk of developing the condition. Which best describes her endometriosis risk profile?

choices.text: High risk due to family history
High risk due to increased age
Low risk due to multiple protective factors

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Low risk due to multiple protective factors

 

Explanation:

The patient has several protective factors against endometriosis, such as:

  • Multiparity (three children)
  • Current use of oral contraceptives
  • Smoking (though smoking has other health risks).

 

Risk Factors

Protective Factors
  • Nulliparous (Increased estrogen)
  • Early Menarche
  • Late Menopause
  • Low BMI
  • Multiparity
  • OCP Use
  • Smoking

 

High risk due to family history (Option A): Family history alone doesn't outweigh her multiple protective factors.

 

High risk due to increased age (Option B): Age is not a primary risk factor for developing endometriosis.

 

Increased risk due to BMI (Option D): High BMI has no risk associated with endometriosis.

questions.text: A 28 year old woman presents with endometriosis lesions on her abdominal surgical scars following a cesarean section. Which theory of endometriosis development best explains this presentation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Direct implantation

 

Explanation:

Direct implantation theory is the best explanation for this case. This theory proposes that endometrial cells can be inadvertently transplanted to other sites during surgical procedures, such as cesarean sections.

 

Sampson's theory (retrograde menstruation) (Option A)explains endometriosis in the pelvic cavity, such as on the ovaries, pouch of Douglas, and uterosacral ligaments, and not in surgical scars.

 

Halban's theory of lymphatic spread (Option B) is used to explain distant sites of endometriosis, particularly in the umbilicus, but not surgical scar endometriosis.

 

Ivanoff's theory of coelomic metaplasia (Option C) is often used to explain endometriosis in unusual locations like the lungs, where peritoneal cells transform into endometrial-like tissue.

questions.text: A 32 year old woman presents with chronic pelvic pain, dysmenorrhea, and dyspareunia. During laparoscopy, the gynaecologist observes endometriotic lesions in multiple locations. Which of the following sites is least likely to be affected by endometriosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Spleen

 

Explanation: Spleen is the least likely site to be affected by endometriosis among the options.

 

Various sites where endometriosis can occur:

 

Pelvic sites (Most common)
  • Ovaries (Commonest)
  • Fallopian tubes
  • Uterosacral ligaments
  • Pouch of Douglas (rectouterine pouch)
  • Pelvic peritoneum

Other pelvic organs
  • Bladder and Ureters
  • Rectum and sigmoid colon

Abdominal sites
  • Appendix
  • Intestine
  • Umbilicus

Surgical scars
  • Cesarean section scars
  • Episiotomy scars

Thoracic sites (rare)

  • Lungs
  • Diaphragm

Extrapelvic sites (very rare)
  • Spine
  • Eyes

 

Vicarious menstruation in endometriosis refers to cyclical bleeding from extragenital sites, such as the nose or lungs, that coincides with the menstrual cycle due to ectopic endometrial tissue.

questions.text: A 35 year old woman undergoes laparoscopy for chronic pelvic pain and infertility. The surgeon observes multiple dark brown lesions on the ovaries and pelvic peritoneum. A biopsy is taken and sent for histopathological examination. Which of the following histopathological findings is most consistent with the diagnosis of endometriosis in this patient?

choices.text: Presence of endometrial glands and stroma without hemosiderin-laden macrophages
Presence of endometrial glands and stroma with hemosiderin-laden macrophages
Presence of only endometrial glands without stroma
Presence of only hemosiderin-laden macrophages without glands or stroma

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Presence of endometrial glands and stroma with hemosiderin-laden macrophages

 

Explanation:

  • The hallmark histopathological finding in endometriosis is the presence of endometrial glands and stroma outside the uterus.
  • In ectopic endometrial implants, hemosiderin-laden macrophages result from cyclic bleeding and red blood cell breakdown.

 

Diagnosis Guidelines:

  • Current guidelines do not require histologic confirmation to diagnose endometriosis, often based on clinical presentation and macroscopic findings during laparoscopy.
  • Macroscopic Findings:
    • Powder-burn or Gunshot Lesions: Dark, blackish-bluish puckered lesions on the peritoneal surface.
    • Clear Vesicles: Small, blister-like lesions on the ovarian surface or peritoneum.
    • Red Polypoidal Lesions: Red, polyp-like, vascularised lesions.
    • White Scarred Lesions: White, scar-like areas with fibrosis and few blood vessels.
    • Yellow-brown Peritoneal Discoloration: Indicates hemosiderin deposition and chronic endometriosis.
  • Correlation of Gross Appearance with Microscopic Findings
    • Red Lesions: Vascularized, indicating active endometriotic tissue.
    • White Lesions: Fibrosis with few vessels, suggesting chronic or scarred tissue.
  • Histologic Examination
    • Hemosiderin Deposition: Common in histologic samples, indicating prior bleeding within the lesion.
    • Histologic Diagnosis Criteria: The presence of both endometrial glands and stroma is required to confirm endometriosis.

 

Endometrial glands and stroma are key, but long-standing lesions typically include hemosiderin-laden macrophages (Option A).

 

Endometriosis diagnosis requires both glandular and stromal components, not glands alone (Option C).

 

Hemosiderin-laden macrophages without endometrial glands and stroma are not specific to endometriosis and can occur in other conditions with chronic bleeding (Option D).

questions.text: A 35 year old woman with a history of endometriosis presents with intermittent right flank pain, hematuria, and recurrent urinary tract infections. Her serum creatinine is elevated at 1.8 mg/dL. A CT scan reveals right hydroureteronephrosis with a stricture at the distal ureter. Which of the following statements is most accurate regarding this patient's condition?

choices.text: This complication occurs in up to 50% of endometriosis cases.
Left-sided involvement is more common than right-sided.
Intrinsic endometriosis of the ureter is more frequent than extrinsic.
Surgical management is typically required for this complication.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Surgical management is typically required for this complication

 

Explanation:

Surgical management is typically required for this complication because ureteral endometriosis causing hydronephrosis and renal function impairment usually necessitates surgical intervention to prevent further kidney damage.

 

Category

Complications

Fertility-related
  • Infertility
  • Increased risk of ectopic pregnancy

Pain-related
  • Chronic pelvic pain
  • Dysmenorrhea
  • Dyspareunia
  • Dyschezia

Organ-specific
  • Gastrointestinal:
    • Bowel obstruction
    • Rectal bleeding
  • Ovarian:
    • Endometriomas
    • Ovarian torsion
    • Rupture of chocolate cyst
  • Urinary:
    • Ureteral obstruction
    • Hydronephrosis

Structural
  • Adhesions
  • Frozen pelvis


 

Ureteral endometriosis is rare, affecting only 0.1-1% of cases, not 50% (Option A).

 

Right-sided ureteral involvement is more common, likely due to left-sided sigmoid colon positioning (Option B).

 

Extrinsic ureteral endometriosis (external compression) is more common than intrinsic (within the ureteral wall) (Option C).

questions.text: A 30 year old woman with chronic pelvic pain, worsening during menstruation, dyspareunia, and dyschezia. Physical exam reveals tender nodules on uterosacral ligaments. Transvaginal ultrasound shows a 3 cm cystic mass with a ground glass appearance in the left ovary. Which is considered the gold standard for confirming the diagnosis of this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Laparoscopy and histopathology

 

Explanation:

This scenario describes a classic presentation of endometriosis, characterised by chronic pelvic pain, dysmenorrhea, dyspareunia, palpable nodules and chocolate cyst.

Investigations for Endometriosis:

  • Ultrasonography (TVS and ERUS): Initial investigation, where endometrioma appears as ground glass opacities and hemorrhagic cysts appear as thread-like structures.

  • Laparoscopy: Investigation of choice, with new lesions visualised as red flame-like and chronic lesions as powder-burnt appearance.
  • Histopathology: Gold standard for confirming the diagnosis, showing blood-filled macrophages (hemosiderophages).

Laparotomy (Option A): Not done for confirmatory purposes due to its invasiveness and higher risk of complications.

MRI (Option C): This is not routinely done but is accurate for diagnosing deep-infiltrating endometriosis (DIE), such as Bowel, Thoracic, Bladder, and Rectovaginal endometriosis, and is done before laparoscopy.

CA 125 Assay (Option D): Non-specific marker, often elevated in endometriosis.

questions.text: A 32 year old woman presents with infertility & dysmenorrhea is diagnosed with endometriosis on diagnostic laparoscopy. The severity of endometriosis is categorised under ASRM staging system for endometriosis, depending on the size of lesions, depth of implants and the extent of adhesions. Which structure is not evaluated for scoring in the ASRM endometriosis staging system?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Retroperitoneum

 

Explanation:

Endometriosis is a chronic condition in which endometrium grows outside the uterus, commonly on the ovaries, fallopian tubes, and pelvic tissues. 

ASRM (American Society for Reproductive Medicine) staging of endometriosis:

It is used to classify the severity and extent of endometriotic lesions found during surgical exploration (usually laparoscopy). 

The location components used for scoring endometriosis according to the ASRM (American Society for Reproductive Medicine) classification system are as follows:

  1. Peritoneal Endometriosis (superficial or deep)(Option D)
  2. Ovarian Endometriosis (superficial or deep)
  3. Posterior Cul-de-sac (Pouch of Douglas) Obliteration (partial or complete) Option B)
  4. Ovarian Adhesions (dense or filmy)
  5. Tubal Adhesions (dense or filmy) (Option A)

Scoring is based on

  • Appearance, size, and depth of implants in the peritoneum & ovary.
  • Presence, extent, and type of adhesions involving the tubes & ovaries.
  • Degree of cul-de-sac obliteration.

The score does not take into account involvement of retroperitoneal structures with deeply infiltrating endometriosis, like rectovaginal septum & rectum.

 

Stage / Classification

Score

Minimal

1-5

Mild

6 - 15

Moderate

16 - 40

Severe

> 40

questions.text: A 30 year old woman with a history of moderate to severe pelvic pain due to endometriosis was prescribed continuous leuprolide three months ago. Despite treatment, she presents again with persistent pelvic pain that interferes with daily activities and quality of life. What is the most appropriate next step in the management?

choices.text: Increase the dose of GnRH agonist

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Laparoscopy

 

Explanation:

Laparoscopy is the preferred next step for moderate to severe pain as it allows for direct visualisation and surgical management of endometriosis, including fulguration of lesions, adhesiolysis, and management of endometriomas. This approach aims to provide symptomatic relief.

 

Management of Endometriosis:

COC - Combined oral contraceptives

CC - Clomiphene citrate

IUI - Intrauterine insemination

 

  • Medical management of endometriosis includes:

Mild pain

Moderate to severe pain
  • NSAIDs & OCPs (First line)
  • Progesterone (Second line)
  • Continuous GnRH agonist (Third line)
  • Continuous GnRH agonist / GnRH antagonist (First line)
  • Laparoscopy, if medical management fails.

 

  • Laparoscopy: Investigation of choice in endometriosis, used for diagnosing, staging, and therapeutic management of pain

 

  • Other Drugs useful in endometriosis are:
    • Aromatase inhibitors (Letrozole)
    • Progesterone receptor modulators (Mifepristone, Ulipristal)
    • GnRH Antagonists (Injection: Ganirelix and cetrirelix)
    • Tab Danazol (400 mg/day)


 

Increase the dose of GnRH agonist (Option A): If the patient is already on continuous leuprolide for three months and still experiencing persistent pelvic pain, increasing the dose is unlikely to provide significant additional benefit and may increase the risk of side effects without improving outcomes.

 

Expectant management (Option B): Given the persistent severe pelvic pain and interference with daily activities despite initial treatment, expectant management is not appropriate as it would not address the ongoing symptoms effectively.

 

Add progestins (Option D): Progestins can be used as an adjunctive therapy in endometriosis management. However, if leuprolide (a potent hormonal treatment) has not sufficiently controlled symptoms, adding progestins may not be effective in achieving adequate symptom relief.

questions.text: A 37 year old woman presents for routine checkup with an ultrasound revealing a 3 cm asymptomatic endometrioma on the left ovary. She expresses that she does not wish to conceive in the future. She has regular cycles, with normal flow & mild spasmodic dysmenorrhea. Given the clinical scenario, what is the most appropriate management strategy for this patient's endometrioma?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Follow-up 6 monthly with transvaginal ultrasound


 

Explanation:

In this scenario, the patient has a 3 cm asymptomatic endometrioma and does not desire future fertility. According to current guidelines, Follow-up 6 monthly with transvaginal ultrasound (TVS) is the most appropriate management for endometrioma as surgical interventions are indicated only for cysts> 5cm.

 

Management of Endometrioma:

  • If the patient wants to conceive:
    • Expectant management is done, irrespective of the size of the endometrioma
  • If pregnancy is not desired:
    • Size < 5cm and Asymptomatic: Follow up six monthly / 1 yearly with TVS
    • Size >5cm: Laparoscopic cystectomy (Option A)
  • Total Abdominal Hysterectomy (Option B):
    • Done only in women > 40 years after completion of family.
    • Prevents the formation of new lesions and pain due to it.
  • Laparoscopy procedures include:
    • Adhesiolysis
    • Fulgration of implants
    • Laparoscopic uterosacral nerve ablation (LUNA)
  • Laparoscopic uterosacral nerve ablation (LUNA) (Option C): It involves disrupting nerve pathways to alleviate pain associated with endometriosis, particularly pelvic pain. It is not indicated for the management of ovarian endometriomas.
  • After surgical procedures, patients require medical management
    • Adolescents <16 years: OCPs
    • Adolescents >16 years: OCPs / GnRH Agonists
    • Adults: OCPs / GnRH Agonists / Progesterone

questions.text: A 40 year old woman comes to the with a history of irregular menstruation, chronic pelvic pain and heavy menstrual bleeding for the past 8 months. Clinical examination reveals a globally enlarged uterus. Which of the following investigations will be the most helpful in diagnosing adenomyosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) USG - TVS with Doppler

 

Explanation:

The given scenario suggests adenomyosis, where USG - TVS with Doppler serves as the first-line and most helpful investigation for diagnosis.

  • Adenomyosis usually occurs in parous women above the age of 40.
  • Presents as Abnormal uterine bleeding with chronic pelvic pain.
  • The uterus is enlarged and globular if the adenomyosis is diffuse.
  • Investigation of choice: TVS preferably with color Doppler
    • Shutter / Venetian Blind sign: Echogenic linear striations indicating endometrial gland invasion into sub-endometrial tissue.
    • Colour Doppler shows central vascularity (whereas leiomyomas show peripheral vascularity)
  • Diagnostic criteria of adenomyosis
    • The asymmetrical thickness of the uterine walls (posterior > anterior)
    • Heterogeneous myometrial echotexture
    • Small myometrial hypoechoic cysts honeycomb appearance
    • Striated projections extending from endometrium to myometrium
    • Endometrial echo poorly defined
    • J–Z thickening ≥12 mm.
  • If USG is inconclusive, an MRI can be done to diagnose adenomyosis.

 

USG - TVS without color Doppler (Option A): It shows adenomyosis features but may cause confusion between submucosal leiomyoma and adenomyosis. Colour Doppler helps to differentiate between them based on the vascularity of the masses.

 

MRI (Option C): Although MRI is more sensitive in diagnosing adenomyosis, it is not the initial investigation of choice as it is not cost-effective. It can be used to diagnose adenomyosis when the USG-TVS is inconclusive.


Hysteroscopy (Option D): It allows direct visualisation of the uterine cavity, but it is invasive and is typically not used to investigate adenomyosis.

questions.text: A 34 year old female presents with chronic, progressive pelvic pain for the past three years and a history of heavy menstrual bleeding. Clinical examination reveals an enlarged uterus corresponding to a size of 10 weeks. An MRI was performed after an inconclusive transvaginal ultrasound (TVS). Which of the following is NOT a typical feature of MRI for adenomyosis?

choices.text: Contrast enhancement does not assist in the diagnosis of adenomyosis.
Presence of myometrial cysts is a characteristic feature.
Myometrial foci appear to have high intensity on the T2 weighted scale.
Junctional zone measures less than 12 mm.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Junctional zone measures less than 12 mm
 

Explanation:

Junctional zone thickening, measuring more than 12 mm, is one of the diagnostic criteria for adenomyosis.

 

Radiological Findings in Adenomyosis:

  • MRI
    • Increased thickness of junctional zone (more than 12 mm) (Option D).
    • The presence of a myometrial cyst is characteristic (Option B).
    • High-intensity myometrial foci on T2 weighted scale (Option C).
    • Administration of gadolinium contrast does not aid in the diagnosis of adenomyosis (Option A)

 

  • USG
    • IOC, but it is not as sensitive as MRI.
    • Shutter / Venetian Blind sign: Echogenic linear striations indicating endometrial gland invasion into sub-endometrial tissue.
    • Colour Doppler shows central vascularity (whereas leiomyomas show peripheral vascularity)

questions.text: A 40 year old female presents with AUB associated with chronic pelvic pain for the past two years. TVS shows anteroposterior asymmetry of the uterus and heterogeneous myometrial texture. What will you most likely see on HPE if this patient is diagnosed with adenomyosis?

choices.text: Glandular endometrial tissue surrounded by stromal cells in myometrium
Hyperplastic endometrial glands with mitotic bodies
Whorled pattern of well-differentiated smooth muscle fibres
Necrotic endometrial tissue with chronic inflammation and lymphocytic infiltrate

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Glandular endometrial tissue surrounded by stromal cells in myometrium

 

Explanation:

Histopathological examination of adenomyosis shows infiltration of the myometrium by the endometrial tissue; thus, we can observe glandular endometrial tissue surrounded by stromal cells in the myometrium.


 

Hyperplastic endometrial glands with mitotic bodies (Option B): Hyperplastic endometrial glands with mitotic bodies are a characteristic finding of endometrial hyperplasia.

 

A whorled pattern of well-differentiated smooth muscle fibers (Option C): Histopathology of Leiomyoma/fibroids shows a well-defined whorled pattern of well-differentiated smooth muscle fibers.

 

Necrotic endometrial tissue with lymphocytic infiltrate (Option D): Necrotic endometrial tissue with lymphocytic infiltration suggests chronic inflammation, which can be seen in endometritis.

questions.text: A 48-year-old multiparous woman with a complete family came to the OPD with complaints of painful menstruation and lower pelvic pain for the past 6 months. Investigations led to a diagnosis of adenomyosis. What is the most appropriate definitive treatment for her condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Total Hysterectomy

 

Explanation:

In a multiparous woman with a complete family, the definitive treatment for adenomyosis is a Total hysterectomy.

Medical Methods

Surgical Methods
  • Combined OCPs and progestin-only regimens: Improves dysmenorrhea and menorrhagia (Option A)
  • NSAIDs: For pain and menorrhagia.
  • LNG-IUS: Reduce Menorrhagia
  • GnRH agonists: For adenomyosis-related sub-fertility or as pre-surgical relief.
  • Danazol: For menorrhagia and pain.
  • Conservative surgery: Preserves fertility for women desiring children. It includes:
    • Adenomyomectomy: Difficulty in completely removing adenomyoma ➜ Risk of recurrence. (Option C)
    • Uterine mass reduction (laparotomy or laparoscopy)
    • Uterine artery embolisation (UAE): To relieve symptoms) (Option D)
  • Definitive surgery: Total Hysterectomy (Option B)

questions.text: A 45 year old woman with AUB and chronic pelvic pain underwent a hysterectomy after failed medical management. HPE from the hysterectomy specimen showed glandular endometrial tissue surrounded by stromal cells in the myometrium. Based on the investigation findings, which of the following conditions is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Adenomyosis

 

Explanation:

In the given scenario, the patient has AUB with chronic pelvic pain and pelvic pressure, and the USG and HPE findings are typical for adenomyosis.

  • Adenomyosis is characterised by abnormal uterine bleeding along with chronic pelvic pain and pelvic pressure due to a large uterus.
  • USG shows a globally enlarged uterus with heterogeneous myometrial texture.
  • Biopsy reveals glandular endometrial tissue surrounded by stromal cells in myometrium.


 

Endometriosis (Option A) presents with chronic pelvic pain, dysmenorrhea, dyspareunia, and infertility, often cyclical.

  • USG shows endometriomas; diagnosis is confirmed by laparoscopy visualising endometrial implants.
  • Histopathology reveals ectopic endometrial tissue.

 

Leiomyoma (Option B) is also characterised by abnormal uterine bleeding, with or without chronic pelvic pain.

  • Histopathology shows a well-defined whorled pattern of smooth muscle fibres.
  • USG reveals a hypoechoic, well-defined mass in the uterus, possibly with mixed echogenicity.

 

Ovarian cysts (Option D) may be asymptomatic or cause pelvic pain and menstrual irregularities. They can be functional or non-functional. USG shows a fluid-filled sac in the ovary.
